I was never a digital only maxi, just for whatever reason, I guess because, you know, when you spend 23 years in the physical to shift totally to the digital and say this is, this is going to be the lane, I just couldn't get there. So I think that probably put me in the position to say, you know, the digital and physical. And I'm not a big fan of the term phigital, but that's, that's what a lot of people seem to use. I mean, you know, we call them garments, but the point being is I wanted that connection. And when I learned about NFC chips, I started to realize that that was the bridge that would really create a, the opportunity for true experience. Right. A lot of brands in the apparel industry for many years would always say, buy into our brand because it's an experience and myself included. And I could even call B's on myself on that now, because looking back, you realize that that just wasn't the case. Like, sure, it extended to the materials. There was tangible intimacy there, as I always like to say, because you could feel the quality and the craftsmanship. But within NFC chip, you can really provide an extended experience in a way that we've just never had the ability to do. Because you can allow the customer at the point of product, the ability to immerse themselves in the brand. And I think that that's really cool because it's literally connected to the product and it allows them to have what we would call zero party or one party data. And you're going to hear a lot of that in the future. speaker: A
text: Two things to jump on there, I think. One, for anybody who doesn't know what NFC chip technology does, quick, if you could explain that quick. And then how it kind of ties into NFTs and like, what the actual connection is there, how does it work and why is it important? And then two, maybe explain a little bit more about the zero party versus third party data, because I think that's important as this conversation goes, too.

speaker: E
text: Yeah, once again, great questions. Appreciate that. So, so when I say NFC chips, it's a near field communication chip. It's been around for 20 plus years now. Dry cleaners have always used them. It's that RFID technology that we all know about. You've got credit cards in your wallet that use tech very similar to this tap two, go tap to pay technology. But it's a chip that really just is a conduit to data. So if you create a digital asset like an NFT and you program the chip to be connected to that through software, you can then scan that chip and pull up the data of the digital asset that it's connected to, in this case, an NFT. Right. And where that becomes interesting is all of the metadata that's associated with that, including provenance data and origin data. So it's not just ownership or authenticity, but if you talk about a physical product, you can start to get supply chain data. So we know sustainability is a big push in apparel. All of that data can be there, all the way back to literally the cotton and the fields that came from, for example. And then your second question, second and third party data, when we think about emails and phone numbers as being the point that gets passed around from company to company data that you can buy easily and then market to individuals through things like social media platforms. That's your typical second and third party data. When we talk about zero and first party data, it's direct connection with the consumer. And this NFC chip is if you put this into a physical product and it doesn't even have to be a peril, it can be any consumer good. We know the consumer owns that product, and you can create that direct relationship not only with them, but their actions. And that gets really, really interesting, because it's the actions of the product, not just my email that exists in a multitude of places, but literally down to the singular product and the consumer that owns it. And I think that that's why I'm so bullish on the technology. It's because there's a massive decline in second and third party data channels, and marketers are finding a massive need now for the zero and first party data as kind of a new frontier. I hope that explained and answered your questions totally.
